utterances: There are a few different things that might be appealing to non-state actors.
For some - now I'm not thinking about the al-Qaidas.
I'm thinking more along the lines of the Hezbollah or Hamas.
They might see themselves as rulers of a state someday.
So there's a reason then to begin to become accountable and to look as they may be responsible officials somewhere down the line.
Future legitimacy.
Future legitimacy.
William Banks is the director of Syracuse University's Institute for National Security and Counterterrorism and a professor of law.
Bill Banks, thank you very much.
It was a pleasure.
The Republican presidential candidates weren't the only politicians locked in debate this weekend.
The House of Representatives was at work until last night before going out on summer recess.
One of the final bills that passed was an overhaul of FISA - the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act.
We heard a lot about why this is a political victory for President Bush.
But with all the talk of political winners and losers, we weren't exactly sure what's in the new bill.
So we asked Tim Starks, a reporter for Congressional Quarterly.
What this does is it allows more warrantless surveillance, especially of anyone overseas.
Sometimes someone who is an American might be on the other line, and they may end up in -swept into surveillance.
But if they're targeting for surveillance on American person on American soil, they need to get a warrant.
But if they're targeting someone who is overseas - and this is important - even if that person is an American, who is overseas, they will not need a warrant for that.
Tim, how's that different from the FISA law that was already on the books?
Well, the main thing is that if any American was involved in any calls, they had to get a warrant to listen in on those calls.
Here, whether or not an American was involved or not, as long as they were targeting that foreign person, they will be able to do that without a warrant.
Now, this bill is only good for six months.

A number of the House lawmakers that I talked to said that they felt like the Senate really made it so that they have no choice but to go along with this bill because they would essentially have been fighting the president and commission(ph) on Republicans by themselves.
And the president had said he would keep them in Congress.
He would keep them in town until they pass the bill he could sign.
He wasn't going to sign a Democrats' bill.
He would have signed this one.

There were a number of them who just wanted to get it over with and felt like, since it is only six months, that it was something they could swallow even if they do not do so at a great deal of enjoyment.
The Democrats have already started talking about how they want to correct some of the things in this bill that they don't like.
This bill really hurt them with some of their liberal constituents and some privacy advocates that are something of a constituency for them.
So they're going to look at scaling back what they've done here and putting in place something permanent that will perhaps satisfy the president and Democrats.
Tim Starks, thanks very much for being with us today.
Thanks very much for having me.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Michele Norris.

On Christmas Eve, New Yorkers seeking a cozy fireplace can turn to channel 11's burning Yule log, but millions of apartment dwellers still opt for a traditional Christmas tree they can decorate, and put presents under.
Every year, all those trees get into all those living rooms with a just-in-time precision that might make FedEx green with envy.
Reporter Bruce Reznik talked with some of New York's Christmas tree sellers, and he has this report.
The generators nearly drown out the little cassette player; the sounds make it clear the street corner Christmas tree sellers are back.
Unidentified Man #1: Did you want a wreath or something else?
Unidentified Man #2: How much is that?
Unidentified Man #1: That one there is a $20.
Every year they come from Alaska and North Carolina and as far away as Quebec and even Sweden.
They start arriving in New York right after Thanksgiving and for the next 3 1/2 weeks, it's a 24/7 push to sell as many trees and wreaths as possible.
It's an annual ritual that's part tradition and part cash hustle.
Forty all together.
So you can put some water when you get home into the base.
And make sure it's a - it's not cold water.
And in the case of a tanda, or what he calls a rotating savings and credit association, your community is helping you save money or get a no-interest loan.
When you participate in a rotating savings and credit association, everybody already knows your name, everybody knows what your social collateral is already, whether you're trustworthy or not.
UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN #1: (Foreign language spoken)
UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN #2: (Foreign language spoken)
UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN #1: (Foreign language spoken)
In San Francisco's Mission District, women are introducing themselves to a group they'll be participating with in a lending circle.
Hi, my name is Alicia Villanueva and I am from Mexico, Mazatlan, Sinaloa.
This is Alicia Villanueva's sixth circle organized by a nonprofit, the Mission Asset Fund.
They're using the tanda system, but reporting payments to credit agencies to help participants build good credit.
There's also zero risk someone will run off with your money.
Nearly 70 percent of the people who participate are women - like Villanueva -- looking to make a better life for their families.
When I arrive, I just start to, you know, cleaning houses and take care of the disabled persons.
But Villanueva really wanted to start her own business selling tamales.
She did tandas back in Mexico, so, when she saw a flyer for something similar run by the Mission Asset Fund, she traveled from two cities away to participate.
Here's how she used her first $1,000 payout.
I remember it was my car, to the DMV registration.
And then the rest of the money I invest on my business.
Villanueva went from selling her tamales door to door to a staff of seven women and a food cart.
She's using this round of cash to buy flyers and signs to help advertise Alicia's Tamales Los Mayas.
So this one is going to support me and can I say catapult me to play in the big leagues.
(LAUGHTER)
Villanueva says the big leagues, for her, means owning a restaurant she can pass down to her three kids.
When I was a kid in the neighborhoods in Central Orange County, the poor neighborhoods, this was a very popular way of getting a loan.
California State Senator Lou Correa calls tandas an alternative to those payday lenders with out of control interest rates.
Lenders, he says, you'll also find in poor neighborhoods like the ones he grew up in.
So, he proposed legislation that would exempt nonprofits like the Mission Asset Fund from having to get a lenders license.
He says they're not lending the money, the participants are, and regulators should get out of the way.

I have to tell you, the lesson for me as the chair of the Banking and Finance Committee in the California State Senate is to, you know, open my eyes a little bit more and start looking at those areas where I think finance does not exist because that will be the place that I may find more solutions to our problems.
Correa says lending circles are responsible for supporting entrepreneurs and job creators like Alicia Villanueva.
And, he says, no matter what you call them - tandas, cundinas, lending circles, rotating savings and credit associations - they work, and it's time they're brought out of the shadows.
Shereen Marisol Meraji, NPR News.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
And you can see more interesting ways women are managing their money at our Tumblr.
Search for She Works Tumblr - without the E.
We also share financial lessons you've learned - good or bad - while you're there.
And stay with us.
